G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: NOW COMES the Plaintiff, Jessica Martinez, and respectfully submits this Complaint for Modification of Custody pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, on the basis of a material change in circumstances that impacts the best interests of the child, Ethan Thompson.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: Plaintiff brings this Complaint for Modification in good faith and in accordance with the principles governing Massachusetts family law, which place paramount importance on the child’s best interests.

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003)..proposition: Plaintiff brings this Complaint for Modification in good faith and in accordance with the principles governing Massachusetts family law, which place paramount importance on the child’s best interests.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003)..support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly reaffirms that in Massachusetts custody matters the ‘best interests of the child’ is the paramount and long-established governing standard. While the case does not discuss a party’s “good faith” in bringing a modification complaint, it squarely supports the asserted principle that Massachusetts family law places paramount importance on the child’s best interests, making it an appropriate authority for that part of the proposition.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 (2003)..relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… and has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt… (best interests standard ‘has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation’); Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas… (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’).”

*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012)..proposition: A parent seeking modification of a custody order must demonstrate a material change in circumstances and that such modification is necessary to promote the child’s best interests.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012)..support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the governing standard for an initial custody determination between parents, focusing on the best interests of the child and the judge’s discretion. It does not address the legal standard for *modification* of an existing custody order or require a showing of a material change in circumstances. Therefore, it does not support the specific modification proposition stated.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012)..relevant_excerpt: “Parents have an equal right to custody of their children. … ‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] … what is “best for the child”…. The determination of which parent will promote a child’s best interests rests within the discretion of the judge … [whose] findings … “must stand unless they are plainly wrong.”’ However, the judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’”

*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.proposition: The Court has the discretion to require supervised visitation or impose conditions when unsupervised visitation poses a risk to the child’s safety or well-being.
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.support_reasoning: The excerpt concerns relocation, paternity, and the limits of a judge’s authority to order a custodial parent to move back to Massachusetts. It does not discuss visitation structure, supervised visitation, or judicial discretion to impose conditions based on safety or well-being concerns. Nothing in the quoted concurrence establishes or affirms a principle about requiring supervised visitation when unsupervised visitation poses a risk to the child.
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.relevant_excerpt: “After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate.”

*Guardianship of Estelle*, 70 Mass. App..proposition: The Court has the discretion to require supervised visitation or impose conditions when unsupervised visitation poses a risk to the child’s safety or well-being.
*Guardianship of Estelle*, 70 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The opinion does not address supervised visitation or the imposition of visitation conditions for a fit parent based on safety or well-being concerns. Instead, it holds that absent a finding of unfitness, the court lacks authority to limit a biological parent’s custodial rights by requiring shared decision-making with guardians, and any limitation must be predicated on unfitness. The only reference to visitation discretion is in a footnote about providing reasonable visitation to the father if guardianship remains, not about supervised or conditioned visitation for child safety.
*Guardianship of Estelle*, 70 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “As we have stated, that solution is not available if the father is found to be fit. … Should such further consideration result in a finding that the father is unfit in the circumstances, it follows that there would not be a transfer of custody and that a guardianship (presumably with the uncle and aunt) might lawfully be maintained. … The judge, of course, would have discretion to provide for reasonable visitation by the father (which the uncle and aunt have never refused in any event).”

*Blixt v. Blixt*, 437 Mass. 649 (2002);.proposition: Evidence of parental substance abuse or intoxication is a valid basis for modifying custody or visitation orders to protect the welfare of the child.
*Blixt v. Blixt*, 437 Mass. 649 (2002);.support_reasoning: The opinion is about the constitutionality and construction of Massachusetts’ grandparent visitation statute in light of parental due process and equal protection rights. It does not involve a custody or visitation modification based on parental substance abuse or intoxication, nor does it discuss substance abuse as a factor in altering custody or visitation. The case instead addresses when and how courts may order third‑party visitation over fit parents’ objections, focusing on harm from loss of a grandparent relationship, not parental misconduct such as substance abuse.
*Blixt v. Blixt*, 437 Mass. 649 (2002);.relevant_excerpt: "It cannot be disputed that the State has a compelling interest to protect children from actual or potential harm. ... As we shall explain more fully below, the statute can be interpreted to require a showing of harm to the child if visitation is not allowed. So interpreted, the statute furthers a compelling and legitimate State interest in mitigating potential harm to children in nonintact families..."

*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.proposition: Evidence of parental substance abuse or intoxication is a valid basis for modifying custody or visitation orders to protect the welfare of the child.
*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal/relocation and modification case focused on the Yannas ‘real advantage’ test and best-interests factors, not on parental substance abuse or intoxication. There is no discussion of either parent’s alcohol or drug use, nor any suggestion that such evidence could be or was used as a basis for modifying custody or visitation. Accordingly, this case cannot be cited as authority for the proposition that parental substance abuse is a valid basis for modifying custody or visitation orders.
*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.relevant_excerpt: In the present case, the judge found, on conflicting evidence, that the proposed move to South Carolina was not in the children’s best interests because of considerations of schooling, housing, transition issues, financial security and separation from family, including their father. Ordinarily we would defer to such findings.

*Adoption of Rhona*, 57 Mass. App. Ct. 4.proposition: Courts may consider the observations and testimonies of third parties, including neighbors and school personnel, as credible evidence of circumstances that negatively impact a child’s environment.
*Adoption of Rhona*, 57 Mass. App. Ct. 4.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss or rely on observations or testimony from neighbors, school personnel, or similar third-party lay witnesses as evidence of the child’s environment. Its evidentiary discussion focuses on the mother’s drug use, medical testimony, §51A reports, foster parents, department social workers, and procedural delays. Because the court neither analyzes nor highlights third-party community or school witnesses as a basis for its decision, the case does not support the specific proposition claimed.
*Adoption of Rhona*, 57 Mass. App. Ct. 4.relevant_excerpt: Notably, the majority of the judge’s findings are based upon the testimony of the Joneses and Ms. Brown. There is no expert testimony concerning the nature of the bonds, any trauma which may result in severing those bonds, and no analysis of methods to alleviate the trauma, if any.

*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).proposition: Courts may consider the observations and testimonies of third parties, including neighbors and school personnel, as credible evidence of circumstances that negatively impact a child’s environment.
*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the trial judge’s weighing of expert and lay testimony and emphasizes deference to credibility determinations, but it does not specifically involve or highlight observations or testimony from third parties such as neighbors or school personnel about the child’s environment. The lay witnesses referenced are mainly family members and social workers, and the key evidentiary discussion centers on expert qualification and methodology. Thus, the case does not stand as authority for the specific proposition that courts may rely on observations of neighbors or school staff as credible evidence of harmful environmental circumstances for a child.
*Adoption of Hugo*, 428 Mass. 219 (1998).relevant_excerpt: “Particularly where, as here, close scrutiny of lay and expert witnesses was central to the judge’s decision, our task is not to decide whether we, presented with the same facts, would have made the same decision, but to determine whether the trial judge abused his discretion or committed a clear error of law. … [T]he judge’s conclusion … was supported by specific and detailed findings demonstrating his close attention to the evidence.”

*Custody of Zia*, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237.proposition: Plaintiff’s concerns about Defendant’s potential substance abuse align with the principle that custody and visitation arrangements should ensure a stable and healthy environment for the child.
*Custody of Zia*, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly applies the overarching best-interests standard, emphasizing the child’s need for appropriate parenting decisions, structure, safety, and stimulation. While it does not focus on "substance abuse" specifically (drug issues are mentioned only as part of background), it clearly affirms that custody and visitation arrangements must ensure a stable, healthy environment and that parental conduct affecting that environment (e.g., unsafe transport, lack of structure, disregard for education) is central to custody determinations. Thus it supports the general principle, though not the specific substance-abuse angle.
*Custody of Zia*, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237.relevant_excerpt: “‘[C]ustody orders and judgments [including those under G. L. c. 209C] are made on the basis of a determination of the best interests of the child . . . .’ … a judge may consider any factors found pertinent to those interests in the circumstances of the dispute. … ‘It is the duty of the judge to consider the welfare of the [child] in reference not merely to the present, but also to the probable future . . . .’ … [T]he judge’s voluminous findings demonstrate consideration of myriad factors and circumstances relevant to the child’s best interests….”

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Ethan’s exhaustion on Mondays raises concerns about his physical and emotional health, which the Massachusetts courts have recognized as critical factors in determining custody arrangements.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the general “best interests of the child” standard for removal and joint custody, but it does not address or analyze a child’s exhaustion on particular days (such as Mondays) or tie such fatigue specifically to physical and emotional health as a factor. While the court recognizes educational, developmental, emotional, and social needs as part of the best-interests inquiry, the specific proposition about Ethan’s Monday exhaustion is not reflected in this decision. Thus, the case is being stretched beyond what it actually says.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “‘[T]he best interests of the child standard is one grounded in the particular needs and circumstances of the individual child in question.’ Adoption of Vito, 431 Mass. 550, 566 (2000). … Where physical custody is shared… the effect of the relocation on the child is a ‘relevant factor[]’ in determining the child’s best interests.”
